author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Army Veteran Gets G.O.P. Nomination for a Hotly Contested Nevada House Seat
description: Mark Robertson’s message centered on protecting freedom of speech and pushing back against government mandates.
content: Mark Robertson, an Army veteran and business owner, has clinched the Republican nomination for a House seat in Nevada with a large campaign war chest and a message centered on protecting freedom of speech and pushing back against government mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Where Did the Black Death Begin? DNA Detectives Find a Key Clue.
description: By fishing shards of bacterial DNA from the teeth of bodies in a cemetery, researchers found the starting point for the plague that devastated Eurasia, they say.
content: Where and when did the Black Death originate? The question has been asked for centuries and led to heated debate among historians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Representative Nancy Mace holds off a Trump-endorsed challenger in South Carolina.
description: Ms. Mace had said the former president’s false claims of a stolen election contributed to the Jan. 6 riot.
content: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Representative Nancy Mace, a Republican who clashed with former President Donald J. Trump after the Jan. 6 attack, fended off a primary challenge on Tuesday from Katie Arrington, a former state representative who had Mr. Trump’s backing. The race was called by The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What the Fed’s rate increase means for credit cards, car loans and student loans.
description: Consumers can expect to pay more for some of life’s most common kinds of borrowing.
content: The Fed’s decision to raise its key interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point is good news for savers, but less so for borrowers: They can expect to pay more on credit card debt, car loans and certain student loans. [Here’s what the Fed’s decision means for mortgages.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Trump and Sanders Opened Doors. Inflation Is Closing Them.
description: What a climate of fiscal constraint means for the populist right and the socialist left.
content: There were many bad things about the period in American politics between Donald Trump’s escalator descent in summer 2015 and the arrival of the Covid pandemic: chaos, polarization, corruption, hysteria, the usual list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Billy Cotton, an Interior Designer for Blue-Chip Artists
description: How the once-struggling decorator became a favorite of Cindy Sherman and other artists.
content: Billy Cotton was in his 20s, newly arrived in Manhattan in the early 2000s and coasting on a cocktail of youthful exuberance, weed and amphetamines, when a fire consumed his apartment in Chelsea, and with it, his sense of a future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Peisner
title: Can Luke Combs, Country’s Everyman, Grow Up Without Losing Touch?
description: The unflashy 32-year-old star makes irrepressibly catchy and relatable country anthems. Now he’s walking a tricky line: finding ways to evolve without straying too far from his roots.
content: CHARLOTTE, Tenn. — On a warm, clear Tuesday in May, Luke Combs offered a visitor a ride around his property in rural Tennessee on one of his Polaris utility vehicles. The 140-acre parcel of forests, fields and streams is about an hour from Nashville. It includes a pool, a beach volleyball court, a chicken coop and a large, white house at the top of a hill where he lives with his wife, who was then eight months pregnant with the couple’s first child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Makes Staff Changes as White House Counsel Departs, Midterms Loom
description: Dana Remus, the president’s top lawyer, will be replaced by her deputy, and Keisha Lance Bottoms, the former Atlanta mayor, is joining the White House staff.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday appointed Keisha Lance Bottoms, the former mayor of Atlanta, as a senior adviser in the White House, further shuffling his senior staff amid a series of high-profile departures heading into the midterm campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Dismisses Bid by G.O.P.-Led States to Defend Trump Immigration Plan
description: The case concerned revisions to the “public charge” rule that made it harder for immigrants who had relied on public assistance to gain permanent legal status.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday dismissed an appeal from several states led by Republicans that had sought to step in to defend a Trump-era immigration policy that the Biden administration has abandoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laszlo Krasznahorkai
title: Many Realities, or None at All
description: In a meditation from a bench in Tompkins Square Park, the Hungarian author Laszlo Krasznahorkai explores a philosophical question.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 15 Father’s Day Recipes That Are No Joke
description: For the dad who has it all, make a meal he won’t soon forget.
content: This Father’s Day, skip the whiskey stones, the razor subscriptions, the graphic tees, mugs and ties in favor of a gift that won’t take up cabinet or closet space: a meal so delicious he won’t want to crack jokes between bites. Whether prepared with the help of the littlest assistants or the inevitable fatherly supervision (“Just checking in!”), he’s sure to feel celebrated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Combat Veteran Wins Nevada House Primary, Playing to Trump’s Base
description: Sam Peters, a retired Air Force major and Bronze Star recipient, will challenge the Democratic incumbent, Steven Horsford, in the Fourth District.
content: A decorated Air Force combat veteran who lined up support from the Trump wing of the Republican Party will face a Democratic incumbent in a tossup congressional race in Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: NATO’s leader pledges more military aid as Ukraine says weapons are slow to arrive.
description: BRUSSELS — NATO member countries will continue to provide Ukraine with heavy weapons and long-range systems, and a new package of assistance to Kyiv will be agreed on by allies in consultation with Ukraine’s defense minister, NATO’s secretary general said on Wednesday.
content: BRUSSELS — NATO member countries will continue to provide Ukraine with heavy weapons and long-range systems, and a new package of assistance to Kyiv will be agreed on by allies in consultation with Ukraine’s defense minister, NATO’s secretary general said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Russia tightens gas supplies to Germany and Italy.
description: Germany says Gazprom aims to drive up fuel prices.
content: Gazprom, the Russian gas monopoly, said on Wednesday that it was further tightening natural gas supplies through a key pipeline to Germany. The company said flows through the pipeline, Nord Stream 1, would be cut by 60 percent, a day after announcing a 40 percent reduction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: We’re Staring at Our Phones, Full of Rage for ‘the Other Side’
description: Once upon a time, social media was going to bring us all together.
content: In theory, American federalism allows a thousand flowers to bloom, as cities and states serve as laboratories of democracy. Transparent governance — sunlight is said to be the best of disinfectants — empowers the electorate to see what its representatives are up to. The internet gives both voice and access to virtually everyone regardless of their status. The surge in small-dollar campaign contributions democratizes the financing of elections, lessening the power of the rich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Lawyer Cited ‘Heated Fight’ Among Justices Over Election Suits
description: In an email weeks after the election, another lawyer advising the Trump campaign responded that the prospect of “‘wild’ chaos” on Jan. 6 could lead the Supreme Court to take up a case.
content: WASHINGTON — A lawyer advising President Donald J. Trump claimed in an email after Election Day 2020 to have insight into a “heated fight” among the Supreme Court justices over whether to hear arguments about the president’s efforts to overturn his defeat at the polls, two people briefed on the email said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhiannon Picton-James
title: Secondhand Wedding Dress Shopping? It’s a Buyer’s Market.
description: “You can find a dress that makes you feel beautiful on a budget — you can save thousands of dollars,” said one bride. “You just have to be willing to do a little digging.”
content: Beverly Yip had always envisioned getting married in a gown from a bridal line like Monique Lhuillier, Berta or Casablanca. The former owner of a rental business that provided linens, glassware and other supplies for weddings, Ms. Yip, who sold that company in 2017, had identified favorite designers by taking note of what other brides were wearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Who Can Write About What? A Conversation With Roxane Gay and Jay Caspian Kang.
description: Two writers debate writing across identity lines — and how to respond when an author gets it really wrong.
content: When does creative license become cultural appropriation? Take “American Dirt” and “The Help,” two books by white authors that drew criticism for their portrayals of characters of color. Artists’ job is to imagine and create, but what do we do when they get it wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron says he wants a Ukrainian victory, but underlines that talks will still be necessary.
description: During a visit to Romania, the French president appeared intent on addressing criticism that he was placing pressure on Kyiv to enter into peace talks.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Wednesday called on Europe to ramp up support for Kyiv, saying he hoped for a Ukrainian victory over Russia, but emphasized that the conflict would eventually have to end at the negotiating table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Says Capitol Marcher Toured With G.O.P. Congressman
description: The committee released surveillance footage of a Capitol complex tour on Jan. 5 and video of a man it said was part of the tour marching toward the Capitol during the riot.
content: WASHINGTON — A man who toured the Capitol complex with a Republican lawmaker the day before the Jan. 6, 2021, attack later marched on the building while making threats against Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other prominent Democrats, the House committee investigating the attack said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Abortions Increase in the U.S., Reversing a 30-Year Decline, Report Finds
description: A new survey of the nation’s abortion providers found increases in every region of the country from 2017 to 2020.
content: The number of abortions in the United States has increased, reversing what had been a three-decade decline, according to a new report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The LIV Golf Controversy Raises Critical Antitrust Questions
description: When is restraint of trade a good thing?
content: Neither antagonist in the fight over golf’s newest league arouses much sympathy. On one side there’s LIV Golf, which is lavishly financed by the sovereign wealth fund of Saudi Arabia, a nation with an execrable record on human rights. On the other there’s the PGA Tour, which is fighting hard to keep its golfers from earning bigger paychecks with LIV Golf, suspending 17 of them for taking part in the LIV Golf Invitational Series. It’s tempting to wish a plague on both their clubhouses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins, Thomas Fuller and Christine Chung
title: Flooding Chaos in Yellowstone, a Sign of Crises to Come
description: Record rainfall and mudslides forced closures just as tourism season ramped up. Virtually none of America’s national parks are untouched by extreme weather and climate change.
content: GARDINER, Mont. — Before evacuating their rental cabin on the edge of Yellowstone National Park, the Manning family watched a nearby house plunge from the riverbank into the raging, flood-swollen waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Exploring Plato and Online Dating, Gibney Dancers Give Their All
description: Gibney Company presents “Up Close, a program of boundary-teasing works by three choreographers.
content: From the first moments of the Gibney Company’s “Up Close” program, at New York Live Arts, the troupe’s superpower is clear: its strong and versatile dancers, artists who appear to be physically capable of anything. Since reinventing itself last year — with a shift toward presenting commissioned works by a variety of choreographers, rather than those of its founder and artistic director, Gina Gibney — the company has seemed to both fill a gap and replicate more of the same in American contemporary dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Dangerously Hot Weather Descends on 100 Million Americans
description: Nearly a third of the U.S. population was under an extreme heat warning, with high temperatures breaking daily records in multiple cities on Wednesday. Heat indexes were expected to reach 110 degrees in some regions.
content: Nearly a third of the U.S. population suffered through blistering conditions on Wednesday, with heat-related warnings and advisories in effect, mostly in the Midwest and Southeast, the National Weather Service said, adding that it may take weeks to see relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: A Medical Frontier
description: Doctors who provide gender-affirming care are split on how to evaluate teens.
content: This summer, the World Professional Association for Transgender Health, an international group of health care professionals, plans to release an update to its guidelines for giving care. The guidelines include a chapter on adolescents that is already generating heat from across the political spectrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Hands-Off Tech Era Is Over
description: More government intervention will slow tech down. Is that good or bad?
content: It’s clear more than ever that governments will no longer leave technology alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leila Slimani
title: Read Your Way Through Paris
description: Leïla Slimani, winner of France’s Goncourt Prize, describes her Paris and recommends books that reveal hidden facets of the city.
content: A few years ago, a young Japanese tourist approached me on the Boulevard Saint-Germain. In a shy voice, she asked, “Where are the writers?” I didn’t understand what she meant. “I would like to see the writers,” she added. “In my guidebook it says that Paris is full of them.” Of course, I smiled and explained to her that times had changed and it was rather rare to see famous writers working in cafes. But I wouldn’t have dreamed of making fun of her, because that’s what I came to Paris for too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What the Fed’s rate increase means for mortgages.
description: Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages track the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds, which are influenced by inflation and the Fed’s actions, among other things.
content: What does the Fed’s decision to raise its key interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point mean for mortgages? [Here’s what the Fed’s decision means for credit cards, car loans and student loans.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Nike Won the Cultural Marathon
description: As the brand turns 50, it’s not letting up.
content: For its 50th anniversary this year, Nike could have done a lot of things. It could have done what many fashion brands do and had a series of enormous parties in multiple capitals around the world with special guests like LeBron James and Billie Eilish and Naomi Osaka and Travis Scott, all of whom work with the brand. It could have issued a limited-edition coffee-table tome full of glossy photos of sneakers treated like art. It could have created “50 and Fabulous” merch (or something).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and John Eligon
title: Ryanair Drops South African Passport Test After Protests
description: The Irish budget airline had imposed a test in Afrikaans, a language with a racist legacy and that many South Africans don’t speak, to weed out fake documents.
content: Ryanair has dropped a requirement that South African passport holders pass a test written in Afrikaans — a language with a racist legacy that many South Africans don’t speak — to prove their nationality before boarding certain flights after the policy was widely criticized as discriminatory and nonsensical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Good Luck to You, Leo Grande’ Review: Pleasure Principles
description: Emma Thompson and Daryl McCormack bring knowing vulnerability to this amusing story of a foxy prostitute and the woman who hires him.
content: If “Good Luck to You, Leo Grande” were a book, it might make a fine choice for a tipsy book club evening. And although the film about an older woman hiring a male prostitute feels ever so briefly like an updated tease of romance-novel fantasies, as directed by Sophie Hyde and written by Katy Brand, “Leo Grande” proves to be a tart and tender probe into sex and intimacy, power dynamics and human connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Yes, You Can Do Better Than the Great American Lawn
description: There are any number of ecologically friendly alternatives to that lawn you’re so proud of — and they look nice, too. Here’s how to start slowly.
content: Daniel Jaffe Wilder still remembers the conversation he had maybe six years ago with a former colleague, when they were working at Garden in the Woods, the native-plant garden in Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Happy the Elephant Doesn’t Have Human Rights, Court Finds
description: Animal advocates had argued that the longtime resident of the Bronx Zoo was imprisoned.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at a court ruling that said Happy the Elephant does not have the same rights as a human. We’ll also look at Mayor Eric Adams’s planned endorsement of Gov. Kathy Hochul and his blueprint for tackling the city’s housing crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: What Europe’s Universal Charger Mandate Means for You
description: From power bricks to cables, it’s time to incorporate USB-C or wireless charging into your setup.
content: Most of us own multiple types of chargers to replenish our devices. That’s because many products, like Apple phones and Microsoft Surface computers, are plugged in with wires that use unique connectors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Mark Guarino
title: John Hinckley’s Sold-Out Brooklyn Concert Is Canceled
description: The venue cited safety reasons in canceling the performance by Mr. Hinckley, who shot President Reagan and has turned to music since being released from a mental health facility.
content: The John Hinckley Jr. concert in Brooklyn, an oddity that was scheduled to feature the music of a man best known for trying to kill a U.S. president, was canceled on Wednesday by the venue, which cited fears of a backlash in a “dangerously radicalized, reactionary climate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger, Michael D. Shear and Dan Bilefsky
title: U.S. and NATO allies send more military aid to Ukraine to counter Russia.
description: After announcing a major new wave of long-range weaponry for Ukraine, Western leaders will turn their sights toward other potential threats to NATO from Russia and China.
content: BRUSSELS — Amid increasingly urgent calls by Ukraine for heavy weapons to fend off Russian’s invasion, President Biden on Wednesday announced an additional $1 billion in weapons and aid for the country, and the United States and its allies sought to present a united front against the Kremlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Inside a Corporate Culture War Stoked by a Crypto C.E.O.
description: Jesse Powell, who leads the crypto exchange Kraken, has challenged the use of preferred pronouns, debated who can use racial slurs and called American women “brainwashed.”
content: Jesse Powell, a founder and the chief executive of Kraken, one of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchanges, recently asked his employees, “If you can identify as a sex, can you identify as a race or ethnicity?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: U.S. and Allies Pledge Additional Arms for Ukraine, but Kyiv Wants More
description: Some NATO countries are wary of sending heavy weapons, hoping for a negotiated truce, but the alliance insists publicly that it is committed to helping Ukraine defeat Russia.
content: BRUSSELS — President Biden on Wednesday announced a further $1 billion in weapons and aid for Ukraine, as the United States and its allies met to craft a response to Ukraine’s increasingly urgent calls for advanced arms to beat back Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The battle for Mariupol came down to a single factory. Will Sievierodonetsk go the same way?
description: The United Nations says that hundreds of civilians are trapped with besieged Ukrainian forces at a chemical plant and “are suffering and experiencing constant shelling and bombardment.”
content: In the end, the battle for the Ukrainian city of Mariupol came down to a showdown over a single big industrial plant. Now, it looks like the fight over Sievierodonetsk in Ukraine’s east might go the same way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Signs Measure to Protect L.G.B.T.Q. Rights, Citing ‘Hateful Attacks’
description: The executive order is designed to counter efforts by Republican politicians like Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who pushed through what opponents have called the “Don’t Say Gay” law.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed an executive order on Wednesday aimed at protecting L.G.B.T.Q. people from a cascade of legislation in conservative states that increasingly targets the rights of gays, lesbians, transgender youth and others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Convicts Man Who Carried Confederate Flag in Capitol Attack
description: Kevin Seefried was found guilty with his son by a federal judge of obstructing the certification of the 2020 presidential vote along with other lesser charges.
content: A Delaware man who flew a Confederate battle flag inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was convicted with his son on Wednesday by a federal judge of the top count in their indictment: obstructing the certification of the 2020 presidential vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Townshend and James Crabtree
title: The U.S. Is Losing Its Military Edge in Asia, and China Knows It
description: America can no longer deter China without help from its allies.
content: A Chinese fighter jet veered in front of an Australian military surveillance aircraft over international waters in the South China Sea last month and released metallic debris that was sucked into the Australian plane’s engines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Glenn Thrush
title: Buffalo Shooting Suspect Is Charged With Federal Hate Crimes
description: The Justice Department has charged the suspect with 26 counts of hate crimes and weapons violations, and could seek the death penalty for some charges.
content: The suspect in the Buffalo massacre that left 10 Black residents dead was charged on Wednesday with federal hate crimes and weapons violations, in a complaint that included new details about the depth of his racist hatred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. advisers recommend authorizing Moderna’s vaccine for children 6 to 17.
description: An expert committee advising the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Tuesday to recommend Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for use in children and adolescents ages 6 to 17. The vote was an important step toward an emergency use authorization.
content: An expert committee advising the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Tuesday to recommend Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for use in children and adolescents ages 6 to 17. The vote was an important step toward an emergency use authorization.

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
title: A brutal urban artillery battle sends civilians running in the east.
description: Heavy volleys between Russian forces taking control of Sievierodonetsk and Ukrainian forces in a neighboring city are leaving wreckage and growing desperation for the residents stuck there.
content: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Vicious fighting raged in Sievierodonetsk on Wednesday after the destruction of a key bridge there in recent days all but cut off the Ukrainian troops fighting to hold the strategically important eastern city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: From the Wreckage of Caribbean Migration, a New Kind of Beauty
description: Four artists created stories of resilience from the traumatic histories of ancestors, on view at the Ford Foundation Gallery.
content: It was curiosity about his own family’s fraught history of migration, from India to Trinidad, that persuaded Andil Gosine, a curator, artist and professor, to begin thinking about ways to connect with other artists who shared his history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Brutal Beating of Women in China Highlights Risk of Saying ‘No’
description: Graphic footage of an attack in a restaurant fueled online debate that showed both the growing awareness of women’s rights and how divisive feminism still remains.
content: BEIJING — The man walked into a barbecue restaurant in northern China and approached a table of three women. He put his hand on the back of one, who shook him off. In response, he slapped her — then, with several other men, savagely beat her and the other women, hitting them with chairs, kicking them and dragging them outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Pregnancy Can Affect the Body Forever. Have Abortion Foes Reckoned With That?
description: Yes, if women are required to go through the ultimate stress test, their liberty is curtailed.
content: Lately, I’ve been thinking a lot about Alexandra of Denmark, Great Britain’s queen from 1901 to 1910. Called “Alix” by her loved ones, she was the wife of King Edward VII, the notoriously promiscuous son of Queen Victoria, dubbed “the playboy prince” by the biographer Jane Ridley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: In ‘Corsicana,’ Will Arbery Puts Art, Family and Down Syndrome Onstage
description: Arbery, a Pulitzer finalist in 2020, is back with a play inspired by his relationship with his sister. But don’t call it an “issue” play.
content: In 2019, Will Arbery scored an unlikely hit with “Heroes of the Fourth Turning,” his darkly comic, boundary-pushing play about young Catholic conservatives debating God, love, friendship and Donald Trump at a late-night party in a Wyoming backyard. A finalist for the 2020 Pulitzer Prize, it won praise both from the heavily liberal New York theater world and from traditionalist Christians who often feel caricatured by it, if they are depicted at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia-Anne Cleary
title: Saying Goodbye to Tommy Shelby, a Traumatized TV Antihero
description: Over the six seasons of “Peaky Blinders,” its central character has grappled with his post-traumatic stress disorder and what redemption could look like.
content: This article contains spoilers for Season 6 of “Peaky Blinders.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Democratic lawmaker will face G.O.P. businessman in Central Valley battleground.
description: Adam C. Gray and John Duarte have both focused on water access for farmers.
content: A Democratic state assemblyman, Adam C. Gray, and a Republican businessman, John Duarte, are headed for a November congressional contest in a Central Valley region that leans Democratic but remains a perennial California battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: These Cupcakes Are Pure Childhood Magic
description: Yotam Ottolenghi’s cream-soda-and-raspberry cupcakes can’t heal the troubles of the world. But they help for a moment.
content: Whenever one of my children reaches a milestone, I become hopelessly teary. Tears of joy? I don’t think so. My tears are for a moment so precious and fleeting that I fear it may be lost. It’s a confusing place in the sad-to-happy range that makes me strangely gloomy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: A top F.D.A. official says very young children need protection from Covid.
description: The remarks by Dr. Peter Marks came at a meeting of an advisory panel weighing whether to recommend that the F.D.A. authorize pediatric vaccines from Moderna and Pfizer.
content: A meeting of outside advisers to the Food and Drug Administration to consider coronavirus vaccines for young children kicked off Wednesday morning with a plea from Dr. Peter Marks, the agency’s top vaccine regulator, about the need to protect children 5 and younger from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: After the Jan. 6 Hearings, Will Trump Face Criminal Charges?
description: Some lawyers and Congress members see the hearings as a road map for the Department of Justice to prosecute Trump.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Drop a Line
description: Rob Baker’s debut brings us a quip with a twist.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor, Rob Baker, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut today. As Mr. Baker mentions in his notes, he has been submitting puzzles on and off for more than 15 years, so major kudos to him for his perseverance!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: What if We Had Spent the Money on Climate?
description: Along with everything else, the pandemic was a huge missed opportunity.
content: When the inflation crisis really arrived last fall, most Americans hoped it would be a passing one — perhaps so “transitory,” some liberals expected, that even if it caused some temporary pain, it need not interfere with anyone’s policy ambitions or basic view of the political moment. As recently as a few weeks ago, many economists believed that the price spikes had peaked, and the country might already be downsloping back to something like normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Winning When Trump Is Against You: A How-To Guide
description: A blueprint is emerging for Republicans who defy the 45th president and still hope to win a G.O.P. primary. Here are five rules of political survival for the aspiring Trump critic.

title: Heading to Ukraine, the Leaders of France and Germany Face a Tense Reception

content: This Tudor Revival-style house, built in 1820 around a 17th-century core and expanded in 1920, sits on the periphery of Calne, a medieval market town in Wiltshire County, in South West England. author: By Molly Young
title: ‘Meet Me by the Fountain’ Takes a Tour of the Mall
description: The design critic Alexandra Lange’s new book considers the rise and fall and dicey future of an American institution.
content: Like people and clouds and cars, malls come in many shapes and colors. But malls have certain bedrock commonalities. A handful of these are physical: food courts, escalators, kiosks, benches, plants, restrooms, parking. Others are intangible. Malls are an ambiguous blend of public and private space — open to all in theory but inaccessible to many in practice. They are recreational zones, community hubs, surveillance centers, temples to consumerism, places where loitering is encouraged until the mall cops kick you out for loitering too much or in the wrong fashion.

content: Josh Jensen, who, after a single-minded quest in the 1970s to find the perfect site in California to grow the pinot noir grape, became the first producer of consistently excellent American pinot noir through his Calera Wine Company, inspiring a new generation of West Coast winemakers, died on Saturday at his home in San Francisco. author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: What if This Wasn’t Menopause After All?
description: The patient had the full suite of symptoms — and a jaw that somehow moved out of alignment. That was the clue something was wrong.
content: The 53-year-old woman bit into her salad, enjoying the crispness. But as she swallowed, a chunk of lettuce stuck in her throat. She coughed, and it loosened and came back up. It was a problem she had frequently these days. Her teeth on the right side of her jaw didn’t touch anymore. It was hard to chew her food well. What was really upsetting was that she’d had this problem before — for most of the previous year. When she couldn’t put up with it anymore, she’d gone to her dentist, Dr. Robert Souferian, in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, who confirmed that her bite had shifted a little. He was reassuring, said that it happened sometimes and offered to file her teeth a little to make the fit better. That worked beautifully — for a few months. But it was now clear that her jaw had shifted again.

author: By Stephen Kearse
title: The Magical Thinking Behind Gun Culture
description: What the Buffalo livestream reveals about the limits of practical regulations in a country so enamored with firearms.
content: In the minutes before an 18-year-old self-proclaimed white supremacist from Conklin, N.Y., drove to a Buffalo grocery store, where he is suspected of shooting 13 people while livestreaming the carnage, he obsessed over his equipment and, implicitly, his legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Lander
title: Investors Deserve to Know the Climate Risks Their Assets Face
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is pushing for more openness by corporations.
content: In 2018, Pacific Gas and Electric estimated that the rise in wildfires, partly driven by climate change, could cost the company $2.5 billion in payouts for recent fires started by its electricity transmission lines and other operations north of San Francisco, and as much as $15 billion in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Joseph Lombardo, Backed by Trump, Will Challenge for Nevada Governor
description: Mr. Lombardo, the sheriff of the Las Vegas area, will face Gov. Steve Sisolak, a Democrat, in what is expected to be one of the most competitive governor’s races in the country.
content: Joseph Lombardo, the sheriff who oversees the Las Vegas area and was endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, has won Nevada’s Republican primary for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: A Three-Peat in Sight, Tampa Bay May Face Its Toughest Test Yet
description: The two-time N.H.L. defending champion Lightning faced elimination in the first round and fell behind, 2-0, in the Eastern Conference finals. Still, a deep Colorado team may be their biggest obstacle.
content: DENVER — The last minutes were ticking away for the Tampa Bay Lightning, along with the dream of hockey immortality. Winners of the last two Stanley Cups, the Lightning trailed the talented Toronto Maple Leafs by a goal late in the third period of a first-round elimination game last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: The Battle Over Gender Therapy
description: More teenagers than ever are seeking transitions, but the medical community that treats them is deeply divided about why — and what to do to help them.
content: Scott Leibowitz is a pioneer in the field of transgender health care. He has directed or worked at three gender clinics on the East Coast and the Midwest, where he provides gender-affirming care, the approach the medical community has largely adopted for embracing children and teenagers who come out as transgender. He also helps shape policy on L.G.B.T. issues for the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. As a child and adolescent psychiatrist who is gay, he found it felt natural to work under the L.G.B.T. “umbrella,” as he put it, aware of the overlap as well as the differences between gay and trans identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Adam Laxalt wins the Republican Senate primary in Nevada, setting up a high-stakes November fight.
description: Mr. Laxalt, a former attorney general of the state who was endorsed by Donald Trump, will face Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat, in one of this year’s pivotal Senate races.
content: Adam Laxalt, a former Nevada attorney general, has won the state’s Republican primary for Senate and will face Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat, in what is likely to be a highly competitive November general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Spigariol, Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas
title: Search for Journalist and Expert in Amazon Becomes Homicide Investigation
description: The police arrested a second suspect after Dom Phillips, a British journalist, and Bruno Araújo Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous people, went missing.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian authorities said on Tuesday that they had arrested a second man in the disappearance of a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous people deep in the Amazon, confirming that their efforts were shifting from a search-and-rescue operation to a homicide investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Déjà Vu in Texas as Astros Pitchers Toss Two Immaculate Innings
description: Luis Garcia and Phil Maton each recorded a three-strikeout inning on nine pitches. That they accomplished the feat against the same three Rangers batters added some absurdity.
content: In the seventh inning of a game between the Philadelphia Athletics and the Chicago White Sox on Sept. 27, 1928, Lefty Grove of the Athletics struck out Moe Berg, Tommy Thomas and Johnny Mostil using only the minimum nine pitches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geraldine Fabrikant
title: Who Will Repair Their Birkins Now?
description: Artbag, the Madison Avenue shop that socialites and celebrities have trusted to restore their chic handbags for 90 years, is closing.
content: June 30 will mark the end of era for a particular set of New Yorkers. That is when Artbag, the go-to store for ladies who lunched (when lunch was a verb) and who needed their choicest handbags repaired and restored for those tony lunches, leaves town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: The Boston Celtics Have Faced Elimination, but Not Like This
description: The Celtics have drawn confidence from previous season-saving wins. But watching a championship trophy drift away is another challenge altogether.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Jayson Tatum offered a resigned chuckle when he was asked about the Boston Celtics’ confidence level after losing Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: A Striking Contrast: Trump Officials Then and Now
description: Many officials have told the Jan. 6 committee that they tried to dissuade the former president from his bid to overturn the election. But in public at the time, their words were far different.
content: The letter was lavish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Pfizer and Moderna Vaccines for Youngest Children
description: States have already ordered millions of doses; if the agency authorizes them in the coming days, babies, toddlers and preschoolers could start receiving shots next week.
content: WASHINGTON — The only Americans still not eligible for coronavirus vaccines — babies, toddlers and preschoolers — appear on the verge of finally getting cleared to receive them after an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines for the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: European Central Bank announces efforts to end bond market turmoil.
description: The bank is concerned about a widening divergence in borrowing costs among the countries that use the euro.
content: The European Central Bank said Wednesday that it would take new steps to ward against spiraling borrowing costs in some highly indebted European countries. The announcement followed an unexpected meeting of bank policymakers looking to soothe growing concerns in the bond market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: A Vaccine for Kids
description: Outside advisers to the F.D.A. moved to authorize vaccines from Moderna and Pfizer for children.
content: Finally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Digging Into Bob Dylan and Lou Reed’s Archives
description: Attempting to uncover unknown things about very well known people.
content: Last month, the Bob Dylan Center opened in Tulsa, Okla., offering researchers unparalleled access to Dylan’s archives and peeling back the layers on his songwriting process, long the object of study and fascination. And this month, “Lou Reed: Caught Between the Twisted Stars” opened at the Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center — it’s the first exhibition drawn from Reed’s archive, which was acquired by the New York Public Library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nada Rashwan
title: Saudi Arabia relaxes some Covid rules before the hajj.
description: Even as coronavirus cases rise steadily, the kingdom has announced the lifting of most Covid precautions as it prepares to receive roughly a million Muslim pilgrims.
content: Even as coronavirus cases rise steadily in Saudi Arabia, the kingdom has announced the lifting of most of its Covid precautions as it prepares to receive roughly a million pilgrims for the annual hajj season, the most since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Can a Law Protecting Endangered Animals Stop New Oil Drilling?
description: Environmentalists say the government failed to study the threats to endangered species from climate change before issuing oil and gas drilling permits.
content: WASHINGTON — A coalition of environmental groups sued the Biden administration on Wednesday for failing to consider the harms caused to endangered species from the emissions produced by oil and gas drilling on public lands.Using a novel legal argument based on the Endangered Species Act, the groups are arguing that oil burned from a well drilled in Wyoming adds to the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere that is heating the planet and devastating coral reefs in Florida, polar bears in the Arctic and monk seals in Hawaii.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: With Northern Ireland and Migrants, Johnson Swings Cudgel of Survival Politics
description: Critics say the British leader’s hardened stances on Northern Ireland and immigration are cynical pandering to the pro-Brexit Tories he needs to stay in power.
content: LONDON — When Prime Minister Boris Johnson survived a potentially lethal challenge to his leadership last week, he said he wanted to pull politics in Britain back to “the issues I think the people in this country want to talk about.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Jim Marchant, a Trump loyalist, is G.O.P. voters’ choice to be Nevada’s top election official.
description: Mr. Marchant, an organizer of the ‘America First’ slate of candidates who deny the 2020 election’s validity, won the Republican primary for secretary of state in a key political battleground.
content: Jim Marchant, one of the organizers of a Trump-inspired “America First” slate of candidates who continue to question the legitimacy of the 2020 election, easily won the Republican nomination for secretary of state in Nevada, a key political battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Vows to Press Ahead With Deportations to Rwanda
description: The government said it would stick with a plan to send asylum seekers to the African country, despite the first flight’s grounding after a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights.
content: LONDON — The plane was preparing for take off, and the small group on board seemed destined to become the first asylum seekers flown 4,000 miles to Rwanda under Britain’s new hard-line migration policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Shauneille Perry Ryder, Pioneering Theater Director, Dies at 92
description: As a Black woman, she blazed a path Off Broadway with an intuitive grasp of “how a story should be told, particularly a Black story,” Giancarlo Esposito said.
content: Shauneille Perry Ryder, an actress, playwright and educator who was one of the first Black women to direct plays Off Broadway, most notably for the New Federal Theater, died on June 9 at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso
title: Chappaqua, N.Y.: A Westchester Hamlet That’s ‘Not Cookie-Cutter’
description: Those looking for a home outside the city praise Chappaqua for its variety of housing and small-town feel.
content: Tara Watnik knew that she and her family would leave their Bronx co-op for a house in Westchester — eventually. But her husband, Scott Watnik, a partner in a Manhattan law firm, grew up in Riverdale, and they liked living in his childhood neighborhood, which was close to her job as a communications director at a private school and an easy commute for him. Then Covid hit, and they decided it was time to get serious about moving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: In ‘Queen,’ the Numbers Don’t Always Add Up
description: Two ambitious scientists are concerned with honey bees in this heady and data-heavy new play, a production of the National Asian American Theater Company.
content: Math is a tool to make sense of the way things work. A minuscule discrepancy becomes the catalyst for a crisis in “Queen,” a heady and data-heavy new play by Madhuri Shekar that opened on Tuesday night at the A.R.T./New York Mezzanine Theater. A hair’s breadth deviation upends not just the outcome of a yearslong study, but how a team of scientists conceive of themselves and life’s purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: An N.F.L. Champion Lives His N.B.A. Dream Through Golden State
description: Ronnie Lott won four Super Bowls with the San Francisco 49ers — but basketball is his favorite sport. He’s all-in on Golden State in the N.B.A. finals.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Ronnie Lott watches Golden State play basketball, he might as well be analyzing old All-22 film of himself from his days as an All-Pro safety and cornerback with the San Francisco 49ers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Why Dogs Can Be So Healing for Kids
description: A new study suggests that spending time with therapy dogs may help lower children’s stress levels even more than relaxation exercises.
content: An unexpected benefit of adopting Annie, my family’s 40-pound, floppy-eared mutt, is the soothing effect she has had on my children. My sons often come home from a long, packed day at school and flop down on the floor next to Annie’s bed, lying quietly while she licks their fingers and cheeks. Or they’ll rub her belly, taking a beat before they pivot to dinner and homework and everything else that needs to happen before they head to bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette, Cade Metz and Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Autopilot and Other Driver-Assist Systems Linked to Hundreds of Crashes
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration released data on 10 months of crashes involving cars with automated components. A few were fatal.
content: Nearly 400 crashes in the United States in 10 months involved cars using advanced driver-assistance technologies, the federal government’s top auto-safety regulator disclosed Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Disney’s ‘Lightyear,’ With a Same-Sex Kiss, Faces a Backlash in Some Muslim Countries
description: The United Arab Emirates banned the animated film, an offshoot of the “Toy Story” movies, from its cinemas. Censors in Indonesia and Malaysia are also considering restrictions.
content: Disney’s new movie “Lightyear,” an offshoot of the “Toy Story” franchise, faces bans or restrictions in parts of Southeast Asia and the Middle East over a scene that features a kiss between two women. The animated film opens around the world this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Real estate companies lay off workers amid ‘clear signals’ of a housing downturn.
description: Redfin and Compass are letting employees go, citing a drop in home sales and rising mortgage rates.
content: The real estate brokerages Compass and Redfin are laying off employees, a sign that the housing market is cooling as higher interest rates make mortgages more expensive and rising inflation squeezes incomes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: $1 Billion to Ukraine
description: Plus the Fed raised interest rates and a video of an assault in China went viral.
content: President Biden said the U.S. would send another $1 billion in equipment and arms to Ukraine. Several other NATO allies also pledged more military help, including ammunition, long-range artillery rocket systems and helicopters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: The Fed Should Make Amends for Its Mistakes
description: A 75-basis-point increase, along with the will to tackle inflation aggressively, would shore up the bank’s shaky credibility.
content: The Federal Reserve’s powerful Open Market Committee will conclude a regular two-day meeting early Wednesday afternoon with an announcement on its next move on interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Ukraine falters in the east.
content: The U.S. will not pressure Ukraine into negotiating a cease-fire even as Russia grinds out steady gains on the ground in the country’s embattled east, Colin H. Kahl, a top Pentagon official, said yesterday. “We’re not going to tell the Ukrainians how to negotiate, what to negotiate and when to negotiate,” he added. “They’re going to set those terms for themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: In Dakar, African Art Speaks in All Its Voices
description: In its first pandemic-era edition, the Dakar Biennale, Africa’s biggest art gathering, is uneven, hectic — and full of possibility.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — Despite the rise to prominence of African contemporary art, its terms are still largely influenced by foreign validators: the mainly Western museums, galleries, collectors and auction houses whose attention anoints stars and assigns value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: If Those Chairs Could Talk
description: The house of Hubert de Givenchy is going up for auction. This week. Christie’s will auction more than 1,200 lots of furniture, sculpture and art that belonged to the designer. His inner circle tells the stories behind the stuff.
content: PARIS — When guests arrived at the Hotel d’Orrouer, the French couturier Hubert de Givenchy’s stately 18th-century mansion here, they rang a polished brass doorbell on the limestone wall. Once the bell was rung — no sound was made — the guardian would open the right side of the monumental evergreen-lacquered double doors and usher in the guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Israel Convicts Palestinian Aid Worker on Charges of Funding Hamas
description: Mohammad El Halabi was charged with funneling millions from a Christian charity to the militant group. The charity, World Vision, said there was no evidence to support that and the trial lacked transparency.
content: An Israeli court convicted a Palestinian aid worker on Wednesday of diverting funds from the charity he worked for to the Palestinian militant group Hamas in a case that spanned six years and drew criticism from rights groups, which said he had been denied a fair and transparent trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross
title: How Much Can the Fed Do?
description: The Fed will conclude its two-day policy meeting today and announce what it will do with the short-term interest rate it sets.
content: Ever since the government reported last week that inflation had sped up in May, economists and investors have been on high alert to see how the Federal Reserve would respond to the threat of surging prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: Constructive Communication Between the U.S. and China Gets Harder
description: Later this month, the United States and China may face another threat in their already fraught relations.
content: At the outset of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidency, many people hoped that relations between the United States and China, after four years of battering, would slowly start to improve. That hasn’t been the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Athens Court Opens Appeals Hearing for Imprisoned Golden Dawn Members
description: Dozens of members of the extreme-right party, which was deemed a criminal organization by the Greek judiciary, were convicted in 2020.
content: ATHENS — Just over a year-and-a-half after the leaders of Greece’s Golden Dawn party and dozens of supporters were imprisoned after the neo-fascist group was deemed a criminal organization, an Athens court on Wednesday began hearing appeals against the convictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Emily Erdos
title: Parents Anxious to Vaccinate Young Children Describe an Agonizing Wait
description: Times readers with babies, toddlers or preschoolers who are unvaccinated against the coronavirus wrote in about worries and strains, loneliness and lost time.
content: Tyfanee Pratt’s son Julian was born in November 2019 in Burlington, N.J. Before long, Ms. Pratt was ready to introduce him to the world. But then, she wrote, “Covid-19 slammed the door on us — locked us in and hid away the key.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China’s Xi offers closer cooperation with Russia in a call with Putin.
description: The Chinese government has tried to keep good ties with Moscow while maintaining that it wants to be an impartial broker for peace in Ukraine.
content: China’s president, Xi Jinping, offered to deepen cooperation with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, in a phone call on Wednesday, signaling that Mr. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine had not dented Mr. Xi’s basic commitment to their partnership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: U.S.G.A. Could Bar LIV Golf Players From Future U.S. Opens
description: “I’m struggling with how this is good for the game,” Mike Whan said of the Saudi-backed rival series that has lured aging stars like Phil Mickelson and Dustin Johnson with big paydays.
content: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Since last week, when multiple top golfers exposed a schism in the men’s professional game by spurning the established PGA Tour to join the upstart, Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit, the sport has been waiting for its power brokers to weigh in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Normalizing Mass Hysteria
description: We are now living in an age of political mass hysteria led by Donald Trump’s election lies.
content: I’m fascinated by mass hysterias. To me, their histories are both mysterious and incredibly revelatory about how human beings can lose themselves, dangerously so, in groupthink, a sort of psychotic contagion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Haigney
title: Meet the Self-Described ‘Bimbos’ of TikTok
description: Can talking about how dumb and hot you are be a feminist act?
content: “Are you a leftist who likes to have their tits out? Do you like to flick off pro-lifers?” Chrissy Chlapecka asks the camera in a 51-second TikTok captioned “BIMBOS, RISE 💖‼️” In the video, Ms. Chlapecka, a 22-year-old comedian who lives in Chicago and has about 4.6 million TikTok followers, is wearing a tight pink minidress, a pink coat trimmed with faux fur and tall white leather boots; her bleach-blond hair is in pigtails. “Are you good at math?” she asks, scribbling “2+2=<3” into a notebook. She holds a pose while reading a book upside down. “Are you good at reading? Well if you are, how?” At the end of the video, she yells out the window: “I’m a bimbo and I’m proud!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine has only a fraction of the weapons it needs from the West, a Kyiv official says.
description: The refrain from Ukraine to its Western allies has been the same since the war began: Give us weapons, and we will beat the Russians so that the rest of Europe can be safe.
